t: To the Chief Musician. To Jeduthun. A Psalm of David.
I*pn said, “I will guard my ways, Lest*ld I sin with my tongue; I*ld will restrain my mouth with a muzzle, While*ld the wicked are before me.”
I*ld was mute with silence, I*ld held my peace even*i from good; And*ld my sorrow was stirred up.
My*ld heart was hot within me; While*ld I was musing, the fire burned. Then*ild I spoke with my tongue:
“Lord,*sln make me to know my end, And*ld what is*i the measure of my days, That*ild I may know how frail I am.*i
Indeed,*ld You have made my days as*i handbreadths, And*ld my age is*i as nothing before You; Certainly*ld every man at his best state is*i but vapor. Selah*ipg
Surely*ld every man walks about like a shadow; Surely*ld they busy themselves in vain; He*ld heaps up riches,*i And*ld does not know who will gather them.
“And*ln now, Lord, what do I wait for? My*ld hope is*i in You.
Deliver*ld me from all my transgressions; Do*ld not make me the reproach of the foolish.
I*ld was mute, I did not open my mouth, Because*ld it was You who did it.*i
Remove*ld Your plague from me; I*ld am consumed by the blow of Your hand.
When*ld with rebukes You correct man for iniquity, You*ld make his beauty melt away like a moth; Surely*ld every man is*i vapor. Selah*ipg
“Hear*pn my prayer, O Lord,*s And*ld give ear to my cry; Do*ld not be silent at my tears; For*ld I am*i a stranger with You, A*ld sojourner, as all my fathers were.*i
Remove*ld Your gaze from me, that I may regain strength, Before*ld I go away and am no more.”
